segments.en: Linked Discourses 55
5. Overflowing Merit, With Verses
41. Overflowing Merit (1st)
“Mendicants, there are these four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.
What four?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
segments.en: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

segments.pli: itipi so bhagavā … pe … satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.
Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako dhamme … pe …
segments.en: the teaching …
the Saṅgha …

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi … pe … samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
segments.en: Furthermore, they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion. …

segments.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puññābhisandā, kusalābhisandā, sukhassāhārā.
segments.en: These are the four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.

segments.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi puññābhisandehi kusalābhisandehi samannāgatassa ariyasāvakassa na sukaraṃ puññassa pamāṇaṃ gaṇetuṃ:
segments.en: When a noble disciple has these four kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to measure how much merit they have by saying that
this is the extent of their overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

segments.pli: Atha kho asaṅkhyeyyo appameyyo mahāpuññakkhandhotveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahāsamudde na sukaraṃ udakassa pamāṇaṃ gaṇetuṃ:
segments.en: It’s like trying to measure how much water is in the ocean. It’s not easy to say

segments.pli: ‘ettakāni udakāḷhakānī’ti vā ‘ettakāni udakāḷhakasatānī’ti vā ‘ettakāni udakāḷhakasahassānī’ti vā ‘ettakāni udakāḷhakasatasahassānī’ti vāti.
segments.en: how many gallons, how many hundreds, thousands, hundreds of thousands of gallons there are.

segments.pli: Atha kho asaṅkhyeyyo appameyyo mahāudakakkhandhotveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of water.

segments.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, imehi catūhi puññābhisandehi kusalābhisandehi samannāgatassa ariyasāvakassa na sukaraṃ puññassa pamāṇaṃ gaṇetuṃ:
segments.en: In the same way, when a noble disciple has these four kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to measure how much merit they have by saying that
this is the extent of their overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

segments.pli: Atha kho asaṅkhyeyyo appameyyo mahāpuññakkhandhotveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchatī”ti.
segments.en: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.”
That is what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
segments.en: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
“Hosts of people use the rivers,
and though the rivers are many,
all reach the great deep, the boundless ocean,
the cruel sea that’s home to precious gems.
So too, when a person gives food, drink, and clothes;
and they’re a giver of beds, seats, and mats—
the streams of merit reach that astute person,
as the rivers bring their waters to the sea.”

sections.title: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of overflowing merit,…

suttaplex.blurb: The four factors of stream-entry—with ethics as the fourth—are streams of merit, and like the ocean cannot be counted. With verses.
